awd_abstract_narration:
Genetics is one of the key foundational subjects for all biology majors and also one of the most challenging for students to learn. A deep understanding of genetics requires students to understand processes that are invisible to the naked eye, master technical jargon, and think mathematically. Many recent national reports have challenged science educators to develop courses that promote a deeper understanding of core biological concepts by adopting teaching approaches that are evidence-based and student-centered instead of asking students to memorize isolated facts.  As teaching techniques in genetics classrooms change, college instructors often struggle to determine if their changes lead to increased student learning. This project, when completed, will provide tools, called concept inventories (CI), needed for educators to determine the level of student understanding and misunderstanding of several core genetics concepts, such as the nature of mutations and how genes interact in a living system. These tools can be used by faculty to determine the teaching methods and classroom practices that best suit the needs of their students. This project aims to improve how biological sciences are learned and taught in college to meet the nation?s need for more and better educated graduates in the biological sciences.

Although multiple broad-spectrum genetics concept tests exist, the intellectual merit of this project is to develop several new concept inventories focused on a range of sub-topics. The project will include faculty and students from community colleges, R1, regional, and small private schools across the country. The first stage will be to gather student responses to open ended questions that require deep understanding of mutations, pedigrees, epistasis, epigenetics, and polygenic inheritance. The second stage will be to develop multiple choice assessments that include student misconceptions that were identified as possible answers in the open-ended responses. The third stage will administer the concept inventories in multiple classrooms across the country to determine whether the concept inventories address the stated course learning objectives, perform similarly in different settings, and can distinguish between high and low performing students. The completed concept inventories will enable instructors to more easily develop and evaluate specific teaching strategies and precisely address misconceptions within each classroom. This project has the potential to positively affect how hundreds of instructors teach genetics and to improve the genetics understanding of thousands of students for years to come. 

This project is being jointly funded by the Genetic Mechanisms Program in the Directorate for Biological Sciences, Division of Molecular and Cellular Biosciences and the Directorate for Education and Human Resources, Division of Undergraduate Education as part of their efforts to address the challenges posed in Vision and Change in Undergraduate Biology Education: A Call to Action (http://visionandchange.org/finalreport/).

por.por_cntn:
The key outcomes for the "Tools in Assessment (TAG)" Grant are: 

1) instrument development,

2)  methods development, and

3) training of graduate students

4) research team building 

 

The instruments we have developed will enable faculty to experiment with and gain evidence for value of particular teaching methods.  The method we developed, distractor congruence testing, has been published twice and will enable other researchers to evaluate the validity of their own evidence-based instruments.  The training we have engaged in has supported the development and training of of six graduate students, as well as enhancing collaboration between four faculty at two different universities.  We have all grown in our abilities over this grant period and will continue to use both the research and the project management lessons we have learned.  The PI team has recently formed two project groups, working with faculty, post-doctoral scholars, and graduate research assistants (GRA) from 8 different academic institutions in 6 different states.  

1. Evaluation Instrument Development and Validation

We developed and calculated validity and reliability measures for three criterion-referenced assessments.  Manuscripts are submitted for two of the three and all are available from the authors via qualtrics. A fourth CRA (Hardy-Weinberg Equilibrium) is in final testing.

Mutation Concept Criterion-reference Assessment (MuCRA)

Wasendorf, Chloe, Joshua W. Reid, Rebecca Seipelt-Thiemann, Z. T. Grimes, Brock Couch, Nick T. Peters, Julia Massimelli Sewall, Audrey L. McCombs, Patrick I. Armstrong, and Nancy Boury. "The development and validation of the mutation criterion referenced assessment (MuCRA)." Journal of Biological Education (2022): 1-15.

Pedigree Analysis Assessment (PACRA)

Grimes, Zachary T., Nancy M. Boury, Chloe Wasendorf, Audrey L. McCombs, Joshua W. Reid, Olena James, Brock Couch, Patrick I. Armstrong, and Rebecca L. Seipelt-Thiemann. "An Assessment to Investigate Student Conceptions of Pedigree Analysis." The American Biology Teacher 84, no. 9 (2022): 535-544.

Epistasis Assessment (EpistCA) 

Wasendorf C, Seipelt-Thiemann R, Couch B, McCombs A, Armstrong PI, Boury N. The Development and Validation of the Epistasis Concept Assessment (Epist-CRA). In preparation, submission expected Spring 2023

 

Two additional qualitative descriptions derived from grant-related activities are also forthcoming: 1) mutation conceptual shifts from first to fourth year (submitted as thesis chapter by Wasendorf), and 2) student conceptual issues with epigenetic concepts (in preparation)

2. Method Development

With significant statistical expertise of graduate student McCombs, we developed a new method of concept assessment validation, congruence testing.  This can be used to directly determine how well the distractors for each item capture student thinking, using advanced statistical modeling and qualitative analysis. We presented this new method at a national Biology Education Research meeting (SABER 2021) and published the method with both the MuCRA and PACRA research papers.

3. Training

Training for this grant has included learning and growing for both graduate students and faculty. Being from different universities and departments, we learned to work together through participation in weekly meetings by phone and then video conferencing, as well as collaboration software, such as google drive, dropbox, and qualtrics to work together.  Additionally, we have engaged in science communication training, as well as disseminating our results in presentations, including seminars/talks (7) and poster sessions (6):

  • Graduate student James presented a poster entitled "Investigating Undergraduate Student Misconceptions Regarding Pedigree Analysis " at the American Society for Biochemistry and Molecular Biology in Orlando, FL in April 2019. https://doi.org/10.1096/fasebj.2019.33.1_supplement.454.13
  • Graduate student Grimes presented a poster entitled "Development of an Assessment Tool for Evaluating Undergraduate Student Understanding of Pedigree Analysis" at the American Society for Biochemistry and Molecular Biology in Orlando, FL in April 2019. https://doi.org/10.1096/fasebj.2019.33.1_supplement.454.9
  • Graduate student Couch presented a poster entitled "Do Student Misconceptions about Mutations Persist throughout College Education?" at the American Society for Biochemistry and Molecular Biology in Orlando, FL in April 2019. https://doi.org/10.1096/fasebj.2019.33.1_supplement.454.5
  • PI Seipelt-Thiemann presented a poster entitled "Undergraduate Student (Mis)understandings of Mutations" at the American Society for Biochemistry and Molecular Biology in Orlando, FL in April 2019. https://doi.org/10.1096/fasebj.2019.33.1_supplement.454.18

4. Team-Building

Drs Seipelt-Thiemann and Boury (PIs) have recruited 2 additional faculty from Illinois College and University of Colorado-Pueblo to expand on a science literacy, digital internship project. The expansion of this project includes plans to form a remote faculty learning community to train additional faculty.  Student interns will annotate scientific podcasts to align the concepts presented in this professional journal club format to the American Society for Microbiology curriculum guidelines.  We plan to create an open access pressbook for use by faculty teaching microbiology.

The PI team (Boury and Seipelt-Thiemann) are also the core of a proposed Research Coordination Network (RCN) dedicated to building a community of faculty creating case studies for Case-Based Teaching of the Vision and Change core concepts.  Of note, 4 of the 6 graduate students involved in the TAG grant have graduated and gone to different institutions as post-doctoral scholars or faculty.  They are, however, consistently contributing to this nascent project.
